course.title: Crime, Journalism and Law
course.description: Examines the prominence of crime narratives in Anglo-American societies in various media formats since the advent of mass communication. Explores why crime has been consistently compelling to societies and citizens, and how these narratives have been harnessed to advance religious, political, governmental and ideological objectives. Critically analyzes the power of mass communication and the impact that crime events have on societies and their legal systems. Questions what responsibilities (if any) media organizations, individual journalists, media consumers, state officials and the legal system assume when producing, consuming and otherwise engaging highly publicized crime events.
